He tells us he is winding down the war — and then says that

press, jails and tortures its political opponents. The people we

oppose.

Housing code protects the off-campus student
By MARTIN FRENCH
One grievance of residents in
off-campus housing, is that
students and poor housing seem
to go together. This can be the
fault of students who as outsiders
don't know that Baltimore has a
housing code which can deal with
slumlords.
Baltimore's housing code
imposes minimum maintenance
requirements particularly
relevant to the "student ghetto."
Houses must not have broken
gutters, leaking roofs, broken or
malfitting doors or windows,
peeling wallpaper or flaking
paint, holes in walls or ceilings,
cracked linoleum, or dripping
faucets.
Post-a-License
In addition to these standards
the housing code requires that
landlords keep hallways lighted
and clean, post a license, provide
hot and cold running water and a
Working shower or tub,
washbasin, and toilet.
Fire provisions require that
houses have not only fire alarms
but also a fire extinguisher at
hand in the building. Landlords
must also heat houses to 70
degrees by day and 60 degrees by

night from October 1 to May I.
When it comes to rats and
roaches the housing code shares
the burdens between tenants and
landlords. If pests are confined to
a flat, its tenants are responsible
for killing the bugs. In fact, the
housing code considers dirty
dishes and dirty stoves as
violations. However, if the house
if full of pests then the landlord
must have them exterminated.
Bill Carter, the city housing
inspector assigned to the Greater
Homewood area, has voiced his
interest in upgrading student
housing.
"One of our (Baltimore
Housing and Community
Development) problems with
housing inspection is that unless
we are notified by a tenant's
complaint, we won't be able to
get to work on a substandard
place," said Carter.
Call Carter
He indicated that if a tenant
has a known violation in his
housing, or wants to find out if
there are violations, the tenant
should call Carter at 889-7927
Monday, Wednesday, or Friday
from 9:00 am to noon or at
889-9430 at other times.

"Let me warn students
though: the presence of a
housing code violation is not a
reason for withholding rent. If
you withhold rent you have
broken your lease and can be
evicted, while the violations
remain," Carter continued. "The
only, violations we can deal with
immediately are leaking roofs,
which must be fixed in 24 hours,
or heat or water system failures
which must be fixed in 48
hours."
Carter noted that it is in any
tenant's interest to notify his
landlord immediately of any
problems or violations in his
housing.

In the words of varsity soccer

ment that run up and down the

season. From the very beginning,

the net.

grounded goalie.

remainder of the first half with

minutes without a goal, until a

permitting Hopkins a penalty
kick.

post away from the Delaware
goalie. This made the final score,
3-2.

[ Dubiel is his own 'rabbit'
Russ Dubiel, who never ran
cross-country until he came to
Hopkins, is rapidly developing
into one of the finest distance
runners in the area and has
unquestionably become the
mainstay of the much-improved
Blue Jay squad.
A junior, earth and planetary
science major, Russ began his
track career in the seventh grade
in his hometown of East
Massapequa Park, Long Island.
Although a top runner
throughout hish school, his
primary interest was soccer, and
he hoped to continue the sport at
Hopkins. In his freshman year,
however, Russ changed his mind:
"I thought it would help my
spring track performance if I ran
cross-country," he recalls, and
the soccer team's loss became the
harriers' gain.
So far, Russ is delighted that
he made the switch, and is very
content with the Hopkins
program. "I like the level of
competition here," he says,"and
since I'm definitely not the best
in the league, there's still
something to work for."
Dubiel reserves his highest
praise for Coach Don Masken,
whom he calls "the best coach
I've ever had." His chief asset,
according to Russ, is his
flexibility -- his knack of
handling different runners in
varied ways. "A guy at Hopkins
is here primarily for an
education," Russ maintains,
"Running is secondary. This
makes it hard on their leader, but
Coach Masken recognizes it and
modifies his policies to suit his

runners. He is more interested in
molding a team than developing a
superstar."
The average cross-country
course spans about five miles, but
Dubiel might prefer it to be a bit
longer. He admits to feeling
"better" after running a slightly
longer distance, and does not feel
that an extended course would
lessen his effectiveness.
The first five finishers on each
team count in the scoring in a
cross-country meet, but if one
team finishes first, second, and
third they win automatically,
regardless of the times of their
next two finishers. It is Russ'job
to make sure that such a sweep
doesn't occur, and to keep pace
with the opposition's number
one man. "I really don't worry
about my time," he asserts. "I'm
out to help the team."
Dubiel prefers to begin a race
quickly, so that he can "start in
front and stay in front," and
likes to know that "there's
nobody for me to catch." This
saves one of his teammates from
having to set the pace for him -- a
tactic many longdistance runners
require -- since Russ is his own
"rabbit."
When he's not running or
studying, Russ finds time to be
co-director of "Chester's Place"
(the Friday night social center of
JHU) and troop coordinator of

the Outing Club. "Since I'm
coordinator," he laughs, "I can
schedule the trips around my
meets."
The success that he's enjoyed
thus far has not made Russ
complacent, but he remains
extremely confident of his
ability. "So far no one's passed
me at the end of a race," he is
quick to point out, and if Russ
Dubiel and Coach Masken have
their way, no one will for quite
some time.

Housing code protects the off-campus student
By MARTIN FRENCH
One grievance of residents in
off-campus housing, is that
students and poor housing seem
to go together. This can be the
fault of students who as outsiders
don't know that Baltimore has a
housing code which can deal with
slumlords.
Baltimore's housing code
imposes minimum maintenance
requirements particularly
relevant to the "student ghetto."
Houses must not have broken
gutters, leaking roofs, broken or
malfitting doors or windows,
peeling wallpaper or flaking
paint, holes in walls or ceilings,
cracked linoleum, or dripping
faucets.
Post-a-License
In addition to these standards
the housing code requires that
landlords keep hallways lighted
and clean, post a license, provide
hot and cold running water and a
Working shower or tub,
washbasin, and toilet.
Fire provisions require that
houses have not only fire alarms
but also a fire extinguisher at
hand in the building. Landlords
must also heat houses to 70
degrees by day and 60 degrees by

night from October 1 to May I.
When it comes to rats and
roaches the housing code shares
the burdens between tenants and
landlords. If pests are confined to
a flat, its tenants are responsible
for killing the bugs. In fact, the
housing code considers dirty
dishes and dirty stoves as
violations. However, if the house
if full of pests then the landlord
must have them exterminated.
Bill Carter, the city housing
inspector assigned to the Greater
Homewood area, has voiced his
interest in upgrading student
housing.
"One of our (Baltimore
Housing and Community
Development) problems with
housing inspection is that unless
we are notified by a tenant's
complaint, we won't be able to
get to work on a substandard
place," said Carter.
Call Carter
He indicated that if a tenant
has a known violation in his
housing, or wants to find out if
there are violations, the tenant
should call Carter at 889-7927
Monday, Wednesday, or Friday
from 9:00 am to noon or at
889-9430 at other times.

"Let me warn students
though: the presence of a
housing code violation is not a
reason for withholding rent. If
you withhold rent you have
broken your lease and can be
evicted, while the violations
remain," Carter continued. "The
only, violations we can deal with
immediately are leaking roofs,
which must be fixed in 24 hours,
or heat or water system failures
which must be fixed in 48
hours."
Carter noted that it is in any
tenant's interest to notify his
landlord immediately of any
problems or violations in his
housing.

By CHUCK SLONIM
In the words of varsity soccer
coach, Robert Oliver, "a soccer
team is divided into two separate
teams; one consists of the ten
ment that run up and down the
field and the other is the
goalkeeper."
Wednesday's game in Newark,
Delaware, at the University of
Delaware, saw the ten-man team
play the best soccer of the young
season. From the very beginning,
the Blue Jay offense and defense
astonished the Blue Hens of
Delaware with tactics that the
Delaware team thought couldn't
exist on the twice-beaten
Hopkins team.
After defeats to Haverford and
Twoson State Colleges, the Blue
Jay soccer team may have looked
ahead to the Delaware games as a
probable loss, due to the team's
reputation and its previous
records. Yet the Jays certainly
didn't let this thought affect
their play. Light blue jerseys
swarmed on every ball in play.
Blue Jay defensive backs, Andy
Smith, Lou Podrazik, John
Goldwine, and Ed Koza surprised
the Blue Hen offensive squad
who are known for their fancy
ball handling and tricky

footwork. The Hopkins midfield
squad did likewise, turning Blue
Hen defensive clears into Blue
Jay offensive plays, tripling the
amount of shots on goal allowed
by Delaware in two previous
games.
As in the past two games, in
which the opponents got the first
goal, Delaware's Jeff McBrearty
put in the first after twenty-five
and a half minutes had gone by
in the first half of the game.
Hopkins' goalie, Keith
Naunheim, blocked a cross from
the left side of the field by Chip
Smallwood but didn't quite tip
the ball high enough to go over
the crossbar. The ball rebounded
off the crossbar onto the foot of
McBrearty who booted it into
the net.
Delaware scored again five
minutes later when a shot from
McBrearty bounced off
Naunheim's chest on to the
awaiting foot of Jerry Cooper of
Delaware who drove it by the
grounded goalie.
Play continued through the
remainder of the first half with
the Blue Jays still as aggressive "then as they were at the start of
the game.
The second half went fifteen

minutes without a goal, until a
Delaware fullback was called for
holding right wing, Phil Heiter, in
the penalty area. Heiter who had
a one-on-one situation with the
Delaware goalie, was fouled by
the Delaware man, thus
permitting Hopkins a penalty
kick.
First Goal _
Freshman Joe Rutkowski
placed the ball into the net off
the goal post. This was the first
goal for Rutkowski in a Blue Jay
uniform.

Ten minutes later, McBrearty
put in his second goal, the team's
third, through the hands of
Hopkins' freshman goalie Jack
Bukowski. But the Blue Jays
refused to give up.
After a series of offensive
thrusts by the Hopkins team,
sophomore Charlie Gilman sent a
rebound from a free kick to the
awaiting foot of Robert Arguero
who placed the ball to the far
post away from the Delaware
goalie. This made the final score,
3-2.

Russ Dubiel, who never ran
cross-country until he came to
Hopkins, is rapidly developing
into one of the finest distance
runners in the area and has
unquestionably become the
mainstay of the much-improved
Blue Jay squad.
A junior, earth and planetary
science major, Russ began his
track career in the seventh grade
in his hometown of East
Massapequa Park, Long Island.
Although a top runner
throughout hish school, his
primary interest was soccer, and
he hoped to continue the sport at
Hopkins. In his freshman year,
however, Russ changed his mind:
"I thought it would help my
spring track performance if I ran
cross-country," he recalls, and
the soccer team's loss became the
harriers' gain.
So far, Russ is delighted that
he made the switch, and is very
content with the Hopkins
program. "I like the level of
competition here," he says,"and
since I'm definitely not the best
in the league, there's still
something to work for."
Dubiel reserves his highest
praise for Coach Don Masken,
whom he calls "the best coach
I've ever had." His chief asset,
according to Russ, is his
flexibility -- his knack of
handling different runners in
varied ways. "A guy at Hopkins
is here primarily for an
education," Russ maintains,
"Running is secondary. This
makes it hard on their leader, but
Coach Masken recognizes it and
modifies his policies to suit his

runners. He is more interested in
molding a team than developing a
superstar."
The average cross-country
course spans about five miles, but
Dubiel might prefer it to be a bit
longer. He admits to feeling
"better" after running a slightly
longer distance, and does not feel
that an extended course would
lessen his effectiveness.
The first five finishers on each
team count in the scoring in a
cross-country meet, but if one
team finishes first, second, and
third they win automatically,
regardless of the times of their
next two finishers. It is Russ'job
to make sure that such a sweep
doesn't occur, and to keep pace
with the opposition's number
one man. "I really don't worry
about my time," he asserts. "I'm
out to help the team."
Dubiel prefers to begin a race
quickly, so that he can "start in
front and stay in front," and
likes to know that "there's
nobody for me to catch." This
saves one of his teammates from
having to set the pace for him -- a
tactic many longdistance runners
require -- since Russ is his own
"rabbit."
When he's not running or
studying, Russ finds time to be
co-director of "Chester's Place"
(the Friday night social center of
JHU) and troop coordinator of

the Outing Club. "Since I'm
coordinator," he laughs, "I can
schedule the trips around my
meets."
The success that he's enjoyed
thus far has not made Russ
complacent, but he remains
extremely confident of his
ability. "So far no one's passed
me at the end of a race," he is
quick to point out, and if Russ
Dubiel and Coach Masken have
their way, no one will for quite
some time.
